awd_titl_txt: Characterization of Near-Field Thermal Radiative Properties of Man-Made Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Man-made materials that are engineered at the very small (nanometer) scale have been proposed for thermal radiation applications. The radiative properties of these materials have been studied theoretically using exact or approximate methods. However, these theoretical predictions have never been experimentally verified. The objective of this project is to experimentally demonstrate that novel thermal radiative properties can be achieved using man-made materials such as metamaterials, gratings, and photonic crystals. The ability to engineer thermal radiation will lead to technological breakthroughs in energy conversion and conservation, and will significantly accelerate the development of thermal radiation applications such as waste heat recovery using nano-gap thermophotovoltaic devices and thermal management at the nanoscale. This will benefit the society by reducing consumption of fossil fuels and thus conserving our limited energy resources and the environment.

The objective of this project is to test the hypothesis that the spectrum of near-field thermal radiation can be tuned using man-made materials that are engineered at the sub-wavelength scale. This hypothesis will be tested by measuring the spectrum of near-field thermal emission from a variety of man-made structures. The measured spectra will be compared with theoretical predictions, and they will be used for validating and tuning the theoretical models. This research will contribute to the advancement of knowledge and technology in the field of nanoscale radiative heat transfer in several ways. It will be experimentally demonstrated that tunable near-field thermal radiation can be achieved using man-made materials. A robust technique will be established for measuring the spectrum of near-field thermal emission. This project will provide physical insight into the mechanisms of near-field thermal emission by man-made materials, and it will help to establish theoretical models that accelerate design and discovery of materials with novel radiative properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
All objects at a temperature greater than absolute zero emit electromagnetic waves, known as thermal radiation. Thermal radiation from an emitting object observed at sub-wavelength (the dominant wavelength of thermal radiation at room temperature is approximately 10 micrometer) distances from the surface of the emitter is referred to as near-field thermal radiation. Near-field thermal radiation exceeds thermal radiation measured at macroscale distances from the emitter by orders of magnitude and it can be quasi-monochromatic (i.e., thermal radiation is dominated by the contribution from a narrow wavelength band). Due to these properties, near-field thermal radiation is very promising for applications such as waste heat recovery using thermophotovoltaic devices, near-field photonic cooling, thermal rectification, and thermal switching. Most of these applications require thermal radiation spectra that are not emitted from natural materials. The objective of this research is to experimentally demonstrate that the spectrum of near-field thermal radiation can be modulated by using man-made materials, i.e., materials engineered at the sub-wavelength scale. This project also aims at educating graduate students and female undergraduate students as well as providing educational opportunities for k-12 students.

During this project, an experimental setup was developed and implemented for measuring the spectrum of near-field thermal radiation. The implemented setup was verified against the known near-field thermal spectra for natural materials. Samples of man-made materials made of silicon carbide nanopillars were fabricated, and their near-field spectra were measured using the implemented experimental setup. It was experimentally demonstrated, for the first time, that the wavelength of the peaks of near-field thermal radiation can be modulated by changing the geometry of the nanopillars. Other outcomes of this project are developing a numerical method for modeling near-field thermal radiation from periodic arrays of sub-wavelength emitters, formulating thermal radiation from spherical particles, which are building blocks for Mie-resonance based man-made materials, unveiling the physics underlying near-field thermal emission from Mie-resonance based man-made materials, and invetigating near-field thermal radiation from on-substarte graphene sheets.

This project also contributed to education and training in the area of mechanical engineering and thermal radiation. Two Ph.D. students, two female undergraduate students, and two male undergraduate students including one honor student were involved and trained in this project. A new course on advanced radiative heat transfer was developed in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Maine. A workshop on spectroscopy of thermal radiation was designed for k-12 students. The workshop includes an interactive minilecture on thermal radiation and a hands-on experiment on building a spectrometer to explore thermal radiation and greenhouse effect. The workshop was held for six different groups of k-12 students including students from rural Maine. Additionally, the PI attended four panel discussions about becoming a female engineer/scientist for high school students from Maine, and she recorded a video about experimental demonstration of emissivity and a video about becoming a mechanical engineer for the outreach office of the College of Engineering at the University of Maine.
